answer_html: The \(1/x^n\) terms go to zero as \(x \to \infty\).
answer_latex: The $1/x^n$ terms go to zero as $x \to \infty$.
hints_html:
What can you do when dealing with a limit at infinity of a rational function?

Only the leading term of a polynomial matters when considering what happens at infinity.
hints_latex:
What can you do when dealing with a limit at infinity of a rational
function?

Only the leading term of a polynomial matters when considering what
happens at infinity.
hints_raw:
What can you do when dealing with a limit at infinity of a rational function?
Only the leading term of a polynomial matters when considering what happens at infinity.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
When considering limits at infinity of rational functions, only the dominant term matters:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{5x^3-2x^2+1}{6x^3+7} &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{x^3 \left( 5 - \frac{2}{x} + \frac{1}{x^3} \right)}{x^3 \left( 6 + \frac{7}{x^3} \right)} \\ &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{5 - \frac{2}{x} + \frac{1}{x^3}}{6 + \frac{7}{x^3}} \\ &= \frac{5}{6}\end{aligned}\]

Here we factored out the leading term (the \(x^3\)) on both the top and bottom. That allowed us to cancel it and then evaluate the rest of the limit. The \(1/x^n\) terms go to zero as \(x \to \infty\).
sols_raw:
When considering limits at infinity of rational functions, only the dominant term matters:
:<math>\begin{align}
\lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{5x^3-2x^2+1}{6x^3+7} &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{x^3 \left( 5 - \frac{2}{x} + \frac{1}{x^3} \right)}{x^3 \left( 6 + \frac{7}{x^3} \right)} \\
&= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{5 - \frac{2}{x} + \frac{1}{x^3}}{6 + \frac{7}{x^3}} \\
&= \frac{5}{6}
\end{align}</math>

Here we factored out the leading term (the <math>x^3</math>) on both the top and bottom.  That allowed us to cancel it and then evaluate the rest of the limit.  The <math>1/x^n</math> terms go to zero as <math>x \to \infty</math>.
